articles.headline: IPhone Use Disappoints; Apple Slides
articles.snippet: Apple’s shares fell 6 percent after AT&T said the early surge of iPhone buyers starting service on its network was smaller than some analysts had anticipated.
articles.abstract: Apple’s shares fell 6 percent after AT&T said the early surge of iPhone buyers starting service on its network was smaller than some analysts had anticipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 — Apple’s shares slumped 6 percent on Tuesday after AT&T said the early surge of iPhone buyers starting service on its network was smaller than some analysts had anticipated.

articles.headline: Law Firms From U.S. Invade Paris
articles.snippet: A quiet revolution is under way, as European law firms are struggling to adapt to successive waves of their British and American counterparts.
articles.abstract: A quiet revolution is under way, as European law firms are struggling to adapt to successive waves of their British and American counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 23 — Jean-Pierre Martel says his most memorable experience with American lawyers came a few years ago when his firm, Rambaud Martel, joined an American law firm to represent a European company preparing to sell shares on the stock exchange.

articles.headline: F.B.I. and Chinese Seize $500 Million of Counterfeit Software
articles.snippet: The arrests and seizures came at a time American politicians and executives are pressing China to take strong measures to curb software piracy.
articles.abstract: The arrests and seizures came at a time American politicians and executives are pressing China to take strong measures to curb software piracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, July 24 — The F.B.I. said Tuesday that a joint effort with the Chinese authorities had led to the arrest of 25 people and the seizing of more than $500 million worth of counterfeit Microsoft and Symantec software that was being made in China and distributed worldwide.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Top Lender Sees Mortgage Woes for ‘Good’ Risks
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans and that the housing market might not begin recovering until 2009 because of a decline in house prices that goes beyond anything experienced in decades.

articles.headline: Libya’s Release of 6 Prisoners Raises Criticism
articles.snippet: The liberation of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor opens the way for Libya to access improved political ties and lucrative trade deals with Europe.
articles.abstract: The liberation of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor opens the way for Libya to access improved political ties and lucrative trade deals with Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 24 — After more than eight years in a Libyan prison, convicted of deliberately infecting children with the virus that causes AIDS, five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor stepped off a French presidential plane to freedom here on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Matthew Brunwasser and Elaine Sciolino

articles.headline: Harley Woos Female Bikers
articles.snippet: Women are buying more motorcycles than ever, and Harley-Davidson is going after that market with a vengeance.
articles.abstract: Women are buying more motorcycles than ever, and Harley-Davidson is going after that market with a vengeance.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — At a recent convention of Harley-Davidson dealers here, Delia Passi, a marketing consultant, was sharing the finer points of selling to women with her audience of about 150, many of whom wore boots, jeans and tattoos. One wore a T-shirt that read, “Born to Party, Forced to Work.”

articles.headline: I.B.M. Plan Ties Training and Accounts
articles.snippet: The company will begin offering its employees in the United States specialized savings accounts for training and education.
articles.abstract: The company will begin offering its employees in the United States specialized savings accounts for training and education.
articles.lead_paragraph: In today’s economy, corporations freely roam the globe for the most efficient, lowest-cost sources of supplies and labor, while American workers are told that the way to compete is constantly to improve their skills with training and education.
